cat:name.gco:CharacterString: Feature Catalog for the Ecological Monitoring Database

cat:scope.gco:CharacterString: The Ecological Monitoring Database is a compilation database that sources data from several similar but distinct sources. The data sources use to develop this database are 1) The Natural Resource Inventory (NRI) dataset on public lands, contained in the Landscape Monitoring Framework (LMF) database, 2) the Bureau of Land Management's (BLM) Assessment, Inventory and Monitoring (AIM) dataset, contained in the Database for Inventory, Monitoring, and Assessment (DIMA) 3) the Nevada Department of Wildlife's (NDOW) Vegetation Habitat Assessment dataset, contained in the DIMA, and 4) Stringham Rangeland Ecology Lab's (University of Nevada, Reno) state and transition ecological monitoring data. The intent of this database is to provide a single source of raw data for running analysis and calculations on.

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Stringham Range Ecology Lab. University of Nevada, Reno.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: County data from the U.S. Census Bureau's Current County and Equivalent National Dataset.
County identifier; a concatenation of Current state FIPS code and county FIPS code.

The GEOID attribute is a concatenation of the state FIPS code followed by the county FIPS code. No spaces are allowed between the two codes. The State FIPS code is taken from "National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States". The county FIPS code is taken from "National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents".
Current state Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States/State Equivalents
Current county Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents.
Current county GNIS code.

INCITS 446:2008 (Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)), Identifying Attributes for Named Physical and Cultural Geographic Features (Except Roads and Highways) of the United States, Its Territories, Outlying Areas, and Freely Associated Areas, and the Waters of the Same to the Limit of the Twelve-Mile Statutory Zone.

National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents.
Current name and the translated legal/statistical area description for county.
The NAMELSAD attribute is a concatenation of the county name followed by the translated legal/statistical area description. No spaces are allowed between the two codes.

Table for recording disturbance sources/types observed during field collection.

A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot. LMF source: POINT - concatenation of STATE, COUNTY, and PSU in that order. DIMA source: tblPlot - PlotKey. UNR source: a concatenation of the date field (YYYYMMDD) the MLRA and a three digit number (000 to 999).

LMF source: Same. This field indicates the year of survey design; data collection may or may not have happened that year. A unique ID for a point includes the fields Survey, State, County, PSU, Point. DIMA source: tblPlots - EstablishDate. Year of the design is not available in the DIMA database. Year of EstablishDate is used instead. UNR source: Date. The year of the Date field.

The date of the survey of the plot, in this case also the establishment date. LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - CAPDATE (UTC time). DIMA source: tblPlots - EstablishDate (local time). UNR source: Date (local time).
LMF source: Same. This field integrates where the disturbance indicators are and when the disturbance occurred. DIMA source: 'NA'. UNR source: 'NA'.
Disturbance is in the general area of the plot and has occurred over one year ago.
Disturbance is in the general area of the plot and had occurred within the last year.
Disturbance is within the plot and has occurred over one year ago.
Disturbance is within the plot and and had occurred within the last year.
Spatial and temporal data about the disturbance was not recorded.

NRCS ecological sites which may be associated with a plot.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code. Primary key for this table, it differs from the ecoid field in that ecological site type (range, forest, etc.) has been stripped. Any underscores and trailing numerical identifiers, if present, are also stripped.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, it is the concatenated form of ecological site type, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code.

The descriptive name of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, it is the concatenated form of three or six other fields. The actual fields that are concatenated together to form this name differ between range and forest ecological sites.
The ecological site type.
Range.
Forest
NRCS Major Land Resource Area ID associated with the ecological site.

The identifier of a particular ecological community found within the plot. For NRCS ecological sites, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code. Differs from a standard NRCS ecological site code in that ecological site type (range, forest, etc.) has been stripped. Sequential number referring to the number of the ecological site identified in the plot. E.g., the first one would be 1, if there is a second one it would be 2, etc.
Which transect the Ecological Site occurring in the plot covers.
The ecological site is found on all transects in the plot.
The northeast to southwest transect.

feet. A unit of length in the imperial and US customary systems of measurement. Since the International Yard and Pound Agreement of 1959, one foot is defined as 0.3048 meter exactly.

The ecological state that the plot is in according to the State and Transition Diagram found within the Ecological Site Description for the observed ecosite. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblPlots - ESD_StateWithinEcologicalSite. UNR source: State.

Records associated with the plant height measurement methodologies.

A unique site identifier for each record. DIMA source: From tblLPIDetail - RecKey. An automatically generated numerical string created at the time of new site creation in the datetime format of YYMMDDHHMMSSR Where R is a random number between 1 and 9999. LMF source: From the POINT table. A string concatenation of the values found in STATE, COUNTY, and PSU (in that order). Additional concatenation of the transect the record is on ('NE','SE','NW', or 'SW') and the number '1'. UNR source: None

This refers to the point in feet on the tape where the height measurement was taken. LMF source: PASTUREHEIGHTS - DISTANCE. This value converted from 'Distance from Start' on two crossing 150 ft. transects to 'Distance from Center' on four radiating 75. ft transects. DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - PointLoc. UNR source: None.

LMF source: Same. This refers to the herbaceous plant species whose height was measured. The code corresponds to a code from the USDA PLANTS database. The species list is from a 2004 PLANTS download for sample years 2011-2012; for sample year 2014, the species list is from 2013. See protocol for rules on what can be hit as well as non-plant codes (Chapter 12). DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - SpeciesHerbaceous. USDA PLANTS database plant code for the tallest herbaceous species within a 15 cm radius cylinder at that location. UNR source: None.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: LMF source: Same. The woody plant species whose height was measured. The code corresponds to a code from the USDA PLANTS database. The species list is from a 2004 PLANTS download for sample years 2011-2012; for sample year 2014, the species list is from 2013. See protocol for rules on what can be hit as well as non-plant codes (Chapter 12). DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - SpeciesWoody. USDA PLANTS database plant code for the tallest woody species within a 15 cm radius cylinder at that location. UNR source: None.
The measurement units used for the height measurement of the herbaceous plant. LMF source: PASTUREHEIGHTS - HEIGHT. DIMA source: 'cm'. UNR source: None.
centimeters
inches. A unit of length in the (British) imperial and United States customary systems of measurement. It is equal to 1/12 foot and defined exactly as 25.4 mm.
feet. A unit of length in the imperial and US customary systems of measurement. Since the International Yard and Pound Agreement of 1959, one foot is defined as 0.3048 meter exactly.
The measurement units used for the height measurement of the woody plant. LMF source: PASTUREHEIGHTS - WHEIGHT. DIMA source: 'cm'. UNR source: None.
centimeters
inches. A unit of length in the (British) imperial and United States customary systems of measurement. It is equal to 1/12 foot and defined exactly as 25.4 mm.
feet. A unit of length in the imperial and US customary systems of measurement. Since the International Yard and Pound Agreement of 1959, one foot is defined as 0.3048 meter exactly.

LMF source: PASTUREHEIGHTS - HIEGHT. The height of the herbaceous plant. "0" means no herbaceous plant present. In 2015, precision of height was specified as follows: To the nearest inch for the first 6 feet, To the nearest foot for 7-60 feet, and As “greater than 60 ft” for trees taller than 60 ft. DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - HeightHerbaceous. Tallest height of the tallest herbaceous plant within a 15cm radius column located 15cm away from the mark (observation side) along the transect. UNR source: None.

LMF source: PASTUREHEIGHTS - WHIEGHT. The height of the woody plant. "0" means no herbaceous plant present. In 2015, precision of height was specified as follows: To the nearest inch for the first 6 feet, To the nearest foot for 7-60 feet, and As “greater than 60 ft” for trees taller than 60 ft. DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - HeightWoody. Tallest height of the tallest woody plant within a 15cm radius column located 15cm away from the mark (observation side) along the transect. UNR source: None.

LMF source: PINTERCEPT - HIT1. This refers to the first layer "hit" in line point intercept (Chapter 9). Possibilities are species codes from USDA PLANTS database as well as non-plant codes (None, HL=Herbaceous Litter, WL=Woody Litter, AL=Artificial Litter, OM=Organic Matter, DS=Deposited Soil, LC=Lichen, M=Moss, RF=Rock Fragments, and codes that start with 2 which are unknown plants; in 2015 litter was simplified to HL, WL, and NL or non-vegetative litter). See protocol for rules on what can be hit in which layer as well as non-plant codes (Chapter 12). The species list is from a 2004 PLANTS download for sample years 2011-2012; for sample year 2014, the species list is from 2013. DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - TopCanopy. USDA PLANTS database plant code (or AIM non-plant code) for the topmost plant touching a vertical line at that point. UNR source: None.

LMF source: PINTERCEPT - HIT2. This refers to the second layer "hit" in line point intercept (Chapter 9). See protocol for rules on what can be hit in which layer as well as non-plant codes (Chapter 12). The species list is from a 2004 PLANTS download for sample years 2011-2012; for sample year 2014, the species list is from 2013. DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - Lower1. USDA PLANTS database plant code (or AIM non-plant code) for the second topmost plant touching a vertical line at that point. UNR source: None.

See protocol for rules on what can be hit in which layer as well as non-plant codes (Chapter 12). The species list is from a 2004 PLANTS download for sample years 2011-2012; for sample year 2014, the species list is from 2013. DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - Lower2. LMF source: PINTERCEPT - BASAL, NONSOIL. This refers to the basal layer "hit" in line point intercept (Chapter 9). Possibilities are species codes from USDA PLANTS database as well as non-plant codes (None, HL=Herbaceous Litter, WL=Woody Litter, AL=Artificial Litter, OM=Organic Matter, DS=Deposited Soil, LC=Lichen, M=Moss, RF=Rock Fragments, and codes that start with 2 which are unknown plants; in 2015 litter was simplified to HL, WL, and NL or non-vegetative litter). See protocol for rules on what can be hit in which layer as well as non-plant codes (Chapter 12). The species list is from a 2004 PLANTS download for sample years 2011-2012; for sample year 2014, the species list is from 2013. Note: in the database, the following logic was used to convert this field: CASE WHEN basal = 'None' AND nonsoil = '' THEN 'S', WHEN basal = 'None' AND non-soil != '' THEN non-soil, ELSE basal. DIMA source: tblLPIDetail - SoilSurface. USDA PLANTS database plant code (or AIM non-plant code) for the bottom most surface touching a vertical line at that point. UNR source: None.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download. 3. Ecology: Native Status

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Native Status and Native Status Jurisdiction code list in the form of "NativeStatusJurisdiction(NativeStatus)". Multiple jurisdictions are separated via a comma.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Native Status and Native Status Jurisdiction codes

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: We have broken the PFA into Native Status jurisdictions to try to improve our information about where plants are native. A plant that is native to any part of a Native Status jurisdiction (e.g., L48, the lower 48 states) is considered Native, even if some populations within that area are introduced. Thus the L48 Native Status value for smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora) is N (Native) despite the existence of introduced populations on the West Coast. However, a plant like dandelion (Taraxacum officinale) is considered Native and Introduced since it has some infra-taxa that are native to L48 and some that are introduced there. Plants that do not occur in the PFA do not have Native Status values in PLANTS, though they may be cultivated or used as ornamentals within the PFA.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The indicator used before the genus name in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two genera.
The genus name of the plant, the first half of the scientific name in biniomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Family.
The indicator used before the species name in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two species.
The species name of the plant, the second half of the scientific name in biniomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Genus.
The indicator used before the subspecies name in the "scientific_name" field (ssp.) which indicates that this plant is a subspecies of another species.
The indicator used before the subspecies name (but after the subspecies prefix) in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two subspecies.
The subspecies name of the plant, the third portion of the scientific name in trinomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Species.
The indicator used before the subspecies name in the "scientific_name" field (var.) which indicates that this plant is a variety (varietas) of another species.
The indicator used before the variety name (but after the variety prefix) in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two varieties.

The variety name of the plant, the third portion of the scientific name in trinomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Subspecies. It is sometimes recommended that the subspecies rank should be used to recognize geographic distinctiveness, whereas the variety rank is appropriate if the taxon is seen throughout the geographic range of the species.
The indicator used before the form name in the "scientific_name" field (f.) which indicates that this plant is a form (forma) of another species/subspecies/variety.
The form name of the plant, the third or fourth portion of the scientific name in the botanical ternary naming system. A taxonomic category that ranks below Variety.

The author citation of the species. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.
Botanist author name abbreviations.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Brummitt, R. K.; Powell, C. E., eds. (1992). Authors of Plant Names: a List of Authors of Scientific Names of Plants, with Recommended Standard Forms of their Names, Including Abbreviations. Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: List of botanists by author abbreviation (A)

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The author citation of the trinomial taxon (subspecies, variety, etc.) in the ternary name of botanical nomenclature. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.

The author citation of the quadrinomial taxon (e.g. form) in the ternary name of botanical nomenclature. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.
In the case that a plant is a hybrid, gives the hybrid parents.
The distribution of the plant within U.S. States, Territories, and Protectorates; Canada Provinces and Territories; Greenland (Denmark), and St. Pierre and Miquelon (France).

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download. 1. Distribution: State and Province

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Distribution codes. State/Province identifiers occur as a comma separated list in the form of "CountryCode(State/Province)

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: The PLANTS database contains native and naturalized plants of the PLANTS Floristic Area (PFA), which consists of North America and all additional U.S. territories and protectorates. Vascular plant distributions are mapped at the state and province level, and by U.S. county. Our checklists for the non-vascular mosses, liverworts, hornworts, and lichens cover all of North America north of Mexico; no additional distribution data are currently available for these plants. Checklist and plant distribution by island and island group for the U.S. territories and protectorates in the PFA Pacific Basin area are in preparation but are not yet included at PLANTS. The total number of PFA accepted taxa at the rank of binomial and below is about 38,000. PLANTS also has about 5000 vascular plants that do not occur spontaneously (i.e., are not naturalized) in the PFA; these are selected if you choose Not in PLANTS Floristic Area. Most of these are of economic importance, and many of them are cultivated within the PFA.

Note associated with the LMF Plant Census protocol, specifically in relation to an unknown/unidentified plant. This a generalized value pertaining to a set of values all starting with 'unknownPlant2' and ending with an unknown plant code and a sequence number (e.g. 1, 2, 3, etc.). The unknown code is created by the data collection system and describes the functional group of the plant. Codes used are as follows (probably, could not track down documentation): ALGA = algae, BRY=bryophyte, CYAN=cyanobacteria, FA=annual forb, FERN=fern, FP=perennial forb, FUNGI=fungus, GA=annual graminoid, GP=perennial graminoid, LICHN=lichen, MOSS=moss, SHRUB=shrub, SLIME=slime mold, SUBS=subshrub, TREE=tree, VH=herbaceous vine, VW=woody vine.
Long form note. LMF source: Same. DIMA source: tblPlotNotes - Note. UNR source: Various Note fields.
Records documenting point locations as originally generated in the sample design.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: ID number for the rectangular area that is the first stage of the two-stage sample design. Each rectangle has three possible points in it, of which the field crews attempt to sample two. LMF source: Same. DIMA source: None. UNR source: None.

The number of the point within the rectangular PSU. The points are the second stage of the two-stage sample design. Field crews go to 1 first, then 2, and then 3 if one of the others failed. LMF source: Same. DIMA source: None. UNR source: None.

LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - TARGET_LATITUDE. Latitude for the plot center location actually sampled, if data collectors were able to capture a GPS location. The latitude is in decimal degrees, NAD83 datum (see Chapter 3 for detailed GPS setup). Note that all numbers are positive--west longitude will have to be changed to negative to be plotted. If "No GPS" column is "successful", assume field_latitude and field_longitude location are the plot location. If "No GPS" column in "GPS" table is "Poor GPS", then this will be blank, and you will have to assume that target_latitude and target_longitude are the plot location. DIMA source: None. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -90. Range Domain Maximum: 90.

LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - TARGET_LONGITUDE. Longitude for the plot center location actually sampled, if data collectors were able to capture a GPS location. The longitude is in decimal degrees, NAD83 datum (see Chapter 3 for detailed GPS setup). Note that all numbers are positive--west longitude will have to be changed to negative to be plotted. If "No GPS" column is "successful", assume field_latitude and field_longitude location are the plot location. If "No GPS" column in "GPS" table is "Poor GPS", then this will be blank, and you will have to assume that target_latitude and target_longitude are the plot location. DIMA source: None. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -180. Range Domain Maximum: 180.

LMF source: POINTWEIGHT - WEIGHT. The number of BLM rangeland acres represented by the plot. It takes into account the sample design for that year as well as points that were not able to be sampled (e.g., non-rangeland, no access). You can use these for state and ecoregion analyses, but not smaller scales (those were not controlled for in calculating the weights). Contact Emily Kachergis for a report that describes the weight calculation process in detail. DIMA source: None. UNR source: None.

LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - SURVEY. This field indicates the year of survey design; data collection may or may not have happened that year. A unique ID for a point includes the fields Survey, State, County, PSU, Point. DIMA source: None. UNR source: None.
latitude, longitude, elevation, and datum converted to Geography data type. Horizontal Datum: NAD83 (srid 4269).
The Sites associated with the point/plot records.

A unique site identifier for each plot/point. Spatial/temporal container for the point. DIMA source: From tblSites - SiteKey. An automatically generated numerical string created at the time of new site creation in the datetime format of YYMMDDHHMMSSR Where R is a random number between 1 and 9999. LMF source: From the POINT table. A string concatenation of the values found in STATE, COUNTY, and PSU (in that order). UNR source: A string concatenation of the MLRA number and the year the data was collected (in that order).

The brief label/name of the site. DIMA source: From tblSites - SiteID. LMF source: FROM POINT - PSU. ID number for the rectangular area that is the first stage of the two-stage sample design. Each rectangle has three possible points in it, of which the field crews attempt to sample two. UNR source: MLRA.
A non-unique label or name associated with the site.
Any long form comments or notes that are associated with the site.
The specific source of the site data (e.g. Entity Name, Program Name, Dataset Name).
The type of data for that site, i.e. the format of the storage container of the raw monitoring data.
Source data from an Assessment Inventory and Monitoring (AIM) style monitoring program with raw data in a Database for Inventory, Monitoring and Assessment (DIMA).
Source data from a Natural Resources Inventory (NRI) monitoring program with raw data in a Landscape Monitoring Framework (LMF) database.
Source data from the Stringham Range Ecology Lab with raw data in a MS Excel Workbook.
Records of plants found during the plant census methodologies.

A unique identifier for each soil pit. LMF source: Concatenation of the plotkey (from the POINT table. A string concatenation of the values found in STATE, COUNTY, and PSU (in that order)) and 'S1'. DIMA source: From tblSoilPitHorizons - SoilKey. An automatically generated numerical string created at the time of new pit creation in the datetime format of YYMMDDHHMMSSR Where R is a random number between 1 and 9999. UNR source: None.

LMF source: Same. A sequential number identifying each of the soil horizons described at the site. Horizons increase in depth with increasing sequence number. You can create a unique ID for each horizon by adding this number to the unique plot information. This protocol was added in 2012. DIMA source: None. Seqnum generated upon import into the database based on its HorizonDepthUpperNum ascending order.

LMF source: Same. The bottom depth of the soil horizon (inches). This protocol was added in 2012. It was originally required only when the ecological site could not be identified. In 2015, this became required at all points for a pit with 20 in minimum depth. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - HorizonDepthLower. This field has been split out into individual plant codes. UNR source: SpeciesList
LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - ESD_Horizon. UNR source: None.
NRCS Horizon and Layer Designations Codes

LMF source: Same. The texture of the soil horizon. Values are in the TextureChoices table; Bedrock was added in 2014. See the protocol (Chapter 7) for detailed information. Standard soils texts (e.g., Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils) are also helpful references. This protocol was added in 2012. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - Texture. UNR source: None.
NRCS Texture Class Codes

LMF source: Same. Soil horizon modifier for rock content (cobbly, etc). Values are in the TextureModifierChoices table. See the protocol (Chapter 7) for detailed information. Standard soils texts (e.g., Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils) are also helpful references. This protocol was added in 2012. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - ESD_HorizonModifier. Data was cleaned and standardized when being pulled in from the data source. UNR source: None.
NRCS Texture Modifier Codes

LMF source: Same. Effervescence classes from a weak hydrochloric acid test. See the protocol (Chapter 7) for detailed information. centimeters
inches. A unit of length in the (British) imperial and United States customary systems of measurement. It is equal to 1/12 foot and defined exactly as 25.4 mm.

A description of where the soil pit was located/dug. LMF source: None. Chapter 7 of the protocol states that pits should be located 'near the point where the two transects intersect'. DIMA source: tblSoilPits - PitDesc. UNR source: None.

The taxonomic description of the soil pedon. Description can be as general as an Order and as specific as a Family. LMF source: None. DIMA source: None. UNR source: Full soil description. Values have been cleaned and standardized.
